Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with severe, life-threatening symptoms of an unknown illness.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: Tonight, the hospital’s fluorescent lights flicker above me as I rush to the emergency room. A patient has just arrived, gasping for breath, his skin clammy and pale. The symptoms are severe, but nothing fits neatly into what I know. As a doctor, I’m expected to diagnose quickly and accurately, to save his life. My mind races through possibilities, but uncertainty gnaws at me. Just as I begin ordering tests, my phone vibrates. It’s a message from Ahmed, a long-time congregant. He pleads for a private meeting tonight—his family is falling apart, and he needs spiritual guidance. As an imam, I am his anchor, the one he trusts to listen and counsel him through his pain. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me: the desperate eyes of my patient, the desperate words of my friend. I can’t be in two places at once. My heart pounds as I stand in the hallway, torn between the duty to heal a body and the duty to heal a soul, knowing that whatever I choose, someone will be left waiting.
